About

This page is to show the work he has been developing through his time in college and his real world career!

Computer science 101

Dr. Anne Foerst Walsh Science Center 111 afoerst@sbu.edu Office Hours: per appointment CS 101-02: Beauty and Joy of Computing Catalog Description This course presents the history, social implications, great principles, and future of computing. It examines the computing applications that have changed the world and how computing empowers discovery and progress in other fields. The relevance of computing to the student and society will be emphasized. Some students will learn the joy of programming using a friendly, graphical language, and will complete a substantial programing project. The course consists of three lecture hours and, for some students, one two-hour laboratory per week. 3-4 credits. You will also create an e-folio that you will work on throughout the semester and will use in the other CS courses. Note: There are some students who will take the lab and some who don’t. Lab and lecture function independently. Textbook You will need an E-subscription to the New York Times which you can get for free at http://nytimes.com/passes Additional readings will be assigned and put on Moodle. The NYT articles will change if there are new developments in the field so please check regularly. Attendance In class, attendance is highly recommended. You have only 2 unexcused absences. For any additional unexcused absence, I will deduct 10% from that weekly grade. Students placed on a mandatory quarantine or in isolation for potential exposure to or con- traction of Covid may electronically send me documentation showing that they are in one of those states, and I will teach the respective classes in dual mode. If you attend via Zoom, your attendance only counts if you have your camera on and are visible on screen (unless you have a good reason not to that you have previously discussed with me). Goals and Learning Objectives CS 101 helps students establish a base upon which to build towards the longer-term goals of the Computer Science and Cybersecurity programs. The course addresses the following goals and objectives that have been established by the department: Goal 1: Discipline Specific Learning Students will be able to understand and apply the theoretical tools of computer science to standard problems from the field. Dr. Anne Foerst Walsh Science Center 111 afoerst@sbu.edu Office Hours: per appointment • Students will learn core concepts of the discipline as determined by a nationally recognized professional computer science education organization. • Students will understand and analyze algorithms written in pseudo-code. • Students will identify the various components of a computer-based system and explain how they integrate to form a coherent solution. Students will document the components in a style commonly used by software professionals. Goal 2: Reasoning and Inquiry Skills Students will be able to read, write, and analyze program fragments and complete programs. Course web page: The course material is available on the Moodle site. There is a Moodle page for the course: CS 101, and a separate Moodle page for the lab: CSL 101. General announcements, readings, assignments, and laboratory exercises for the course will be given in class AND published on the Moodle sites. Students are expected to check Moodle regularly for news and assignment deadlines Dishonesty Policy If a student fails to prove that he or she has done work by herself (that is: the student cannot answer questions about it in class), it has to be re-done. If there is any evidence of plagiarism, the work will be graded “F”. After cheating once, the student has to sign a confession that is given to their Dean. Cheating twice leads to failure of the class. For the University Policy, please see https://web.sbu.edu/friedsam/governing/academic_policies/academic_honesty_policy.pdf. Large Language Model (LLM) Policy Writing is an essential form of critical thinking and problem-solving as well as an ethical endeavor expressive of the university's values. Large Language Models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT, GPT 4 and Bard are AI-based tools that identify patterns in large collections of text, culled from various sources including especially webpages on the internet, and then reproduce those patterns in response to prompts by users. LLMs can generate texts in a very short amount of time, making it seemingly easier and more efficient to search for and find summarized information and ideas related to the subject of interest. However, there are ethical considerations for using them including but not limited to the fact that their data is taken from writers without reimbursing them, and that they often repeat racist, sexist, and classist language that one can unfortunately find online. You can also be kept from critical thinking when using them. For these and other reasons, this is why some instructors will prohibit any use of LLMs. I allow the limited use of LLMs. However, if you submit work that makes use of LLMs you need to do the following: Dr. Anne Foerst Walsh Science Center 111 afoerst@sbu.edu Office Hours: per appointment • You need to examine and evaluate the information generated by LLMs, as they may produce irrelevant or inaccurate information, i.e. hallucinations. You need to check the source of the information and cite it properly. Texts generated by LLMs, copied and submitted as your final writing is considered a violation of the university’s academic honesty policy. • You should explicitly acknowledge the assistance of LLMs in the creation of your work (sections or parts that included ideas/issues initially identified via LLMs, or tasks achieved such as editing and paraphrasing, or calculations). • When submitting larger works, you should provide an audit trail of queries (for example, a transcript of queries and responses) and a reflection report/note, as specified by the instructor. • I will carefully inspect any texts that are suspected of plagiarism or have been generated largely by AI, as indicated by detection software. I will make a judgment on such cases to take the most appropriate action, taking into consideration the context of the course and the specific assignment. Title IX Title IX makes it clear that violence and harassment based on sex and gender are Civil Rights offenses subject to the same kinds of accountability and the same kinds of support applied to offenses against other protected categories such as race, national origin, etc. If you or someone you know has been harassed or assaulted, you can find the appropriate resources at the Health and Wellness Center (https://www.sbu.edu/life-at-sbu/student-health-safety- conduct/health-counseling-services), or at the Campus Safety Office (https://www.sbu.edu/life-at-sbu/campus-safety). For on-campus reporting, see the Title IX Coordinator (716) 375-2102, and Residence Life Staff (RAs, RDs, and other professional staff). The University's policy and procedures regarding gender-based and sexual misconduct can be found online at https://www.sbu.edu/docs/default-source/life-at-sbu-quick-center/student- conduct/code-of-conduct/23-24-student-code-of-conduct.pdf In the event of an emergency, call: (716) 375-2525. Be also aware that most university employees are mandated reporters. Students with Disabilities Students with disabilities who believe that they may need accommodations in this class are encouraged to contact the Disability Support Services Office, Doyle room 26, at 375-2065 as soon as possible, to better ensure that such accommodations are implemented in a timely fashion. For more information, please see https://www.sbu.edu/life-at-sbu/services-for- students/disability-services. Cyber Security 101

Syllabus 2024 1. Course Number and NameCYB 101: Introduction to Information Security 2. Credits and Contact Hours three credit hours Office Hours: Email or Slack me to schedule an appointment. 3. Instructor Name Jason Langston Email: Jlangston@sbu.edu 4. Textbook Title: Fundamentals of Information Systems Security Authors: Kim & Solomon Edition: 4th Edition ISBN: 1284220737 Publisher: Jones & Bartlett Learning 5. Course DescriptionThis course introduces two primary domains of Information Security and Information Assurance, as the CompTIA Security+ certification exam covers. By the end of the course, students will have demonstrated proficiency in critical areas through various assessments, including written assignments, objective tests, case studies, classroom discussions, and hands-on labs. The objectives include: Defining information security and understanding its significance. Identifying types of attackers, analyzing vulnerabilities, and suggesting appropriate defenses. Exploring various software security applications and vulnerability scanning tools. Understanding logical and physical access controls, authentication, authorization, and accounting. Defining and explaining risk management and penetration testing. This course is crucial as security incidents continue to rise. It aims to equip students with the necessary skills to protect both personal and organizational data while raising awareness of the evolving social and technical factors that drive the need for these protective measures. In today's digital age, the importance of information security cannot be overstated, making this course more relevant than ever. Required for: Cybersecurity major 6. Course OutcomesUpon completion of this course, students will be able to: Navigate Bash and PowerShell command-line environments. Create simple Bash and PowerShell scripts. Understand laws and regulations guiding cybersecurity across various industries and countries. Develop a general understanding of attacks and defenses. Grasp the components and standards of the CIA triad. 7. Topics CoveredThe course will cover the following topics: Threats and Adversaries (e.g., threat actors, malware, natural phenomena) Common Attacks Basic Risk Assessment Security Life-Cycle Security Mechanisms (e.g., Identification/Authentication, Audit) Separation of Domains and Duties Isolation Layering (Defense in Depth) Least Privilege Endpoint Protection Social Engineering and People Security Cyber Defense Partnerships (Federal, State, Local, Industry) Insider Threats Threat Information Sources Security Program Goals and Objectives Security Policies 8. Grading Your grade will be determined based on the following: Grading Scale: Weekly QuizzesA weekly open-book quiz will be administered in person to assess comprehension of the material. The quiz will primarily focus on textbook content but may include additional concepts covered during lectures. Quizzes are generally scheduled for Fridays, though this may vary. 9. Additional Information Program Goals:Detailed learning goals for the Cybersecurity program can be found in the SBU Cybersecurity BS Catalog. Academic Dishonesty Policy:Cheating or plagiarism will result in a zero for the assignment, with the potential to fail the course depending on the severity. Refer to the University Policy on Academic Honesty for more information. Students with Disabilities:Students requiring accommodations should contact the Disability Support Services Office, Doyle, room 26, at 375-2065 as soon as possible. More details are available at SBU Disability Services. LabsLabs will emphasize the importance of command-line environments in cybersecurity. The focus will be on mastering Windows and Linux command-line syntax and related tools. Attendance & ParticipationRegular attendance is expected and will be recorded at the start of each class. Attendance and participation will influence your mid-term and final grades. Excused absences, discussed in advance, will be considered case-by-case. Final Project The final project will involve comprehensive analysis and documentation of files, IPs, and domains suspected to be involved in malicious activities. The project will include the following sections: Executive SummaryProvide a concise overview of the analysis process, highlighting key findings. File AnalysisAnalyze files of interest and document details such as file names, hashes, MIME types, file sizes, and relevant screenshots. IP AnalysisEvaluate suspicious IP addresses and their associations, including GeoIP location and registration details. Domain AnalysisInvestigate domains involved in potential threats, documenting associated IPs and registrar information. Malware AnalysisUse file hashes to search online services and summarize the results, noting any commonalities among reported malware. Sandbox AnalysisUtilize AnyRun for sandbox analysis of suspicious files and interpret the results. Research and ReportingConduct in-depth research on selected malware samples and report on their purpose, distribution, and persistence mechanisms. Format and SubmissionThe final report must be organized and concise and submitted via Moodle by the end of the course’s scheduled final exam time. Schedule The course schedule is subject to change based on class needs, with prior notice provided. Due to holidays or breaks, content may be carried over from the previous week. Labs OverviewThe labs will cover topics such as: Windows Command Line: Navigation, redirection, and pipelining. Linux Command Line: Navigation, interpreters, and other command-line basics. Advanced Windows Command Line: Command help, variables, copying, and moving files. Advanced Linux Command Line: Hashing and environment context introduction. PowerShell: Looping, variables, and object manipulation. Bash Scripting: Looping and variables. PowerShell Objects: Working with objects and file hashing. PowerShell File Hashing: Looping, hashing, and object manipulation. Bash File Hashing: Looping and hashing basics.

Computer Science 131

CS131 Object Oriented Programming Fall 2024 Instructor Dr. Zahmeeth Sakkaff Email: zssakkaff@sbu.edu Office: 110 Walsh Credit Hours: 4 Student Meetings Email to setup an appointment. Required Text Roman Lysecky and Adrian Lizarraga, Programming in Java. This is an online textbook that is available at zybooks.com. This is a required textbook that you may not share since it records individual student progress. Obtaining the text: 1. Sign in or create an account at learn.zybooks.com. 2. Enter zybook code: SBUCS131SakkaffFall2024 3. Subscribe using any credit card. Cost is $89. 4. You must purchase the book to complete assignments for the course. If you have alternate arrangements with the university for textbook purchases, please work with your advisor and they will be able to process this for you. Students may begin subscribing on Aug 12, 2024 and the cutoff to subscribe is Dec 02, 2024. Subscriptions will last until Dec 30, 2024. Course Webpage In general, announcements, readings, assignments, and laboratory exercises for CS and CSL 131 will be given in class and published on the Moodle course site: https://sbuonline.sbu.edu/course/view.php?id=2986. Students are expected to check Moodle regularly for news, and are nonetheless responsible for any assignment announced in either manner. Course Slack Channel The course has a Slack channel in our SBU Computing Slack community: https://join.slack.com/t/sbu-computing/shared_invite/zt-22g630fy8-cKRllN3YB7TnD9uLrMQdZg. It is recommended to join as this is a good way to communicate with your instructor and classmates. You will receive an invite to the channel via email. Course Description This is the first course in the computer science major sequence. The course introduces the object-oriented approach to software design using the programming language Java. Topics covered are software design, implementation and testing, basic computer organization and source code translation. No previous programming experience is presupposed. The course consists of three lecture hours and one two-hour laboratory per week. 1 Note: The course may not be taken for credit without the laboratory component. Objectives Students will be able to design programs using the object-oriented design methodology and will be able to implement and test programs using the object-oriented programming language Java. They will be introduced to the principles of software engineering, in particular the practice of designing large programs using modules, which can be specified, implemented, and tested independently. Students will be able to manipulate the simple and composite data types. They will also be introduced to basic computer organization and data representation at the machine level. Attendance Policy A major goal for this course is for students to satisfactorily demonstrate the knowledge, skills and dispositions as described in the course’s objectives. Attendance is critical to achieving those objectives, and it is the students’ responsibility to attend the course on a regular basis. If you are feeling sick, please do not come to class and follow up (via digital communication) with the instructor to discuss what you missed. If a situation arises in which you must miss multiple lectures, please contact the instructor as soon as possible. Assignment due dates will not be adjusted in response to any absences. Exceptions to this policy may be made on a case-by-case basis when there are extenuating circumstances, however this must be discussed with the instructor before the assignment due date. Academic Honesty Policy Enrollment at St. Bonaventure University requires adherence to the University’s standards of academic integrity. These standards may be intuitively understood and cannot, in any case, be listed exhaustively. The following examples, detailed in full in Appendix A of the Code of Conduct (http://www.sbu.edu/codeofconduct), represent some basic types of unacceptable behavior: cheating, plagiarism, fabrications, obtaining an unfair advantage, aiding and abetting academic dishonesty, falsification of records and official documents, and unauthorized access to records. Academic dishonesty is a serious matter and will be dealt with accordingly, with University sanctions ranging from grade alteration to the possibility of expulsion. Students should familiarize themselves with these very important provisions of the Academic Honesty Policy, which is outlined in the Code of Conduct for reference only. Acts of academic dishonesty are not processed through the University Judicial process; the process for handling alleged violations is outlined within the policy. Students with Disabilities Policy Students with academic or personal support needs should see Disability Support Services (Plassmann 100D, 375-2065) as soon as possible Grading Item Percent of Final Grade Quizzes 20% 200 points Labs 50% 500 points 2 Reading Assignments Final Project Total Points 10% 100 points 20% 200 points 1000 points • Your grade in this course will be based on the following ranges: A 90% and above B+ 85% to 89% B 80% to 84% C+ 75% to 79% C 70% to 74% D 65% to 69% F 0% to 64% Chapter Quizzes Closed-book quizzes will be given at the end of a unit in-class via Moodle to assess how well you understood the covered material. Labs There is a two-hour lab each week. Labs must be submitted via Moodle. Attendance at laboratory sessions is strongly recommended but not required if you can complete the lab on your own equipment. Attending the lab session is the best way to get assistance from your instructor. The labs will all be available at the beginning of the semester and can be re-attempted as many times as you would like. There will be no specific schedule to the labs as far as sessions on Mondays and Wednesdays. Textbook Assignments Sections of the online textbook are assigned through the ZyBooks software that pertain to the material being covered in the course. Students are expected to read the sections assigned and complete all the activities in the sections. Final Project The final grade for this class is a project that will be assigned in the final weeks of the semester. The final session for our class is scheduled for May 4, 2024 from 1:10 PM – 3:40 PM and will be available to work on your project. Attendance & Participation As discussed in the attendance policy above, you are expected to attend class on a regular basis. Attendance will be taken at the start of every class. Absences that are discussed with the instructor will be handled on a case-by-case basis and will have little-to-no impact on your grade. 3 Schedule Week Date Quiz Chapter Topics 1 Tue Aug 27 Thu Aug 29 1 1 Introduction to Computers and Programming 2 Tue Sep 03 Thu Sep 05 3 Tue Sep 10 Thu Sep 12 4 Tue Sep 17 2 Variables and Assignments 2 3 Branches Thu Sep 19 3 5 Tue Sep 24 4 Loops Thu Sep 26 6 Tue Oct 01 Thu Oct 03 7 Tue Oct 08 8 5 Arrays 4 5 Arrays Thu Oct 10 5 Tue Oct 15 Thu Oct 17 6 6 7 User Defined Methods Break Break Oct 14 - 15 No Classes Objects and Classes Inheritance Inheritance Input/Output Recursion Exceptions Review Final Session Scheduled for last day of the class 9 Tue Oct 22 Thu Oct 24 7 10 Tue Oct 29 Thu Oct 31 11 Tue Nov 05 Thu Nov 07 8 12 Tue Nov 12 Thu Nov 14 9 13 Tue Nov 19 Thu Nov 21 10 14 Tue Nov 26 Thu Nov 28 11 15 Tue Dec 03 Thu Dec 05 8 8 9 10 11 4

Spanish 201

1 St. Bonaventure University Department of World Languages 3 credits and Cultural Studies SPANISH 201- Intermediate Spanish Prereq: SPAN 102 Professor: Dr. José M Medrano Office: Plassmann Hall 208 Telephone: 716-375-2321 E-mail: jmedrano@sbu.edu Office Hours: MWF 10:20 AM – 11:20 AM or by appointment Class Location: Plassmann Hall 014 Meeting Times: T/Th 10:00 AM – 11:15 AM Text: Blanco, José A., Donley, Philip Redwine. PANORAMA: Introducción a la lengua española (6th edition), Vista Higher Learning, 2021. Additional Resources: PANORAMA Supersite vhlcentral.com, and Student Activities Manual/WebSAM. Course Description: Intermediate-level Spanish grammar with reading, practice in conversation and language analysis of selected literary texts and cultural materials. Course Outcomes: This course fulfills Goal One of the Learning outcomes of the Department of World Languages and Cultural Studies: for the student to be able to understand intermediate concepts in the target language and be able to better communicate in the language in a variety of daily situations. Additionally, the student will continue to have an understanding and exposure to various cultural phenomena and elements of both Latin American and Spanish life. The student will, through a variety of group and individual work in written, oral and spoken exercises, know the illustrated vocabulary and grammar of pertinent text chapters. The student will be able to communicate by using the present, past, and imperfect indicative tenses as well as the present and imperfect subjunctives. The student will also be able to communicate using the future and conditional tenses as well as a variety of perfect tenses in both the indicative and the subjunctive. Students will also be able to read and write using the aforementioned tenses and vocabulary. Learning Outcomes: The Learning Outcomes for the Department of World Languages and Cultural Studies can be found at: https://www.sbu.edu/academics/world-languages-and-cultural-studies Grading Scale: A: 95-100 A-: 90-94 B+: 87-89 B: 83-86 B-: 80-82 C+: 77-79 C: 73-76 C-: 70-72 D+: 67-69 D: 64-66 D-: 61-63 F:0-60 Grade breakdown: Participation 10% 100 points Homework 30% 300 points (75 points each chapter) Film 10% 100 points Exams (3) 37.50% 375 points (125 points each) Final Exam 12.50% 125 points 1,000 in total Grade components: Participation (10%): 2 This refers to how much you participate; your attitude toward your fellow classmates, your instructor, and the activities; your preparedness for the class; and your attendance. All these factors are of paramount importance: language acquisition is a process, and it is cumulative. Therefore, in order to comprehend and produce Spanish, you must consistently and actively participate in our class discussions and activities. Your class participation will be graded according to the following criteria: - Superior (90-100%): I attend class every day, arrive on time, and do not leave early. I listen carefully when others speak and volunteer often. I speak only Spanish. I actively participate with enthusiasm and a positive attitude in all activities. My presence makes a positive impact on what we do in class. - Above-average to average (70-90%): I attend class every day, arrive on time, and do not leave early. I volunteer occasionally and generally listen to the instructor and others, but sometimes I get distracted. I speak mostly Spanish in class but use English, too. I show interest and participate in all activities, sometimes actively, sometimes passively. - Unsatisfactory (below 70%): I occasionally miss class, and sometimes arrive late or leave early. I rarely volunteer. I use more English than Spanish in class. I do not pay active attention to classroom activities. Instead, I do homework, sleep, read the newspaper during class activities. I am not interested in-class activities. ATTENDANCE: A major goal for this course is for students to satisfactorily demonstrate the knowledge, skills, and dispositions as described in the course's objectives. Attendance is critical to achieving those objectives, and it is the students' responsibility to attend the course as much as they can without putting themselves, the instructor, or their classmates at risk. Students placed on a mandatory quarantine or in isolation for potential exposure to or contraction of COVID-19 may electronically send the instructor documentation showing that they are in one of those statuses, and the instructor will then make accommodations for those students within the confines of the course objectives. ATTENDANCE POLICY: Sickness with documentation, athletics/ROTC, religious observances, and university-sponsored events are excused absences. Other absences (oversleep/hangover/studying for another class/skipping/family trips, etc.) are unexcused, and you cannot make up assignments if your absence is unexcused. I will take attendance using the app "Acadly." No more than three absences will be allowed. After that point, 5 points for each class missed will be deducted from the attendance grade. Two tardies, leaving early or leaving during class time equals one absence. Six or more unexcused absences will result in a final grade of an "F." Electronics Policy: No texting or cell phone use during class–it is very distracting for everyone. Turn off any and all alerts on any device. Given the kinds of activities that we will do in this class, the print version of the textbook and traditional means of note-taking are preferred; however, laptops and tablets may be used in the classroom for these purposes. Students observed using irrelevant websites or software, or whose devices distract classmates, will be asked to shut their devices off for the remainder of the class period. Texting in class or using an electronic device other than to use the eBook will result in a penalty of -5 points. COVID-19: If we go online to maintain social distancing, you are expected to attend all Zoom meetings and be on time. You must be prepared for class by having your book open, the camera/microphone on, and you must be in a professional setting. Please see the "Student Code of Conduct," which outlines all students' responsibilities as members of the St. Bonaventure University community. Homework (30%): SUPERSITE: Extensive homework will be assigned daily – listening, speaking and written activities assigned in Supersite. Your daily homework assignments will be graded automatically. Late assignments will not be accepted for credit. You can and should do the Supersite activities as many times as you need for extra practice and review, including those that aren't assigned. Remember, 30% of your grade is based on these online workbook assignments. The importance of doing your homework cannot be 3 exaggerated since consistent, daily practice with Spanish is vital to your success! Test items will be modeled after homework. You have to dedicate about 2 hours a week to the Supersite. Film (10%): During the semester, a film from the Spanish-speaking world will be assigned. You will need to watch the movie and answer questions related to the main themes of the movie. Exams (40%): These will closely reflect the activities that you do in and out of class. There will be sections on oral and reading comprehension, as well as sections on the vocabulary, grammar, and cultural content of the chapter. All exams must be taken at their scheduled times. The best preparation for these exams will be your daily active participation in activities during and outside of class. No make-up exams will be given without written proof of an emergency. Final Exam (10%): The final exam will only cover Chapter 11. December 12, 2024: 1:10 PM- 3:40 PM ACADEMIC HONESTY POLICY: You may consult the Academic Honesty Policy here: https://my.sbu.edu/docs/default-source/student-services/code-of-conduct.pdf?sfvrsn=bbe 74298_10#page=37 Accessibility Services and Academic Support: St. Bonaventure University strives to ensure the accessibility of its programs, classes, and services for all students. Students with disabilities who need academic accommodations should contact the Accessibility Services and Accommodations office, located on the first floor of Plassmann in room 108, at asa@sbu.edu or at 716-375-2115. Additional information about accommodations can be found here: https://www.sbu.edu/asa. Please reach out early in the semester so that we can assist you as soon as possible. Documentation from the Accessibility Services Office is required before the instructor can make accommodations. WELLNESS CENTER: If you are sick, please contact the Center for Student Wellness, located in Doyle Hall 122, telephone 716-735-2310. Bona 101

BONA 101: Introduction to St. Bonaventure (3 credits) Class time: 1:00 pm – 2:15 pm T/TH Instructor: Molly Moretti moretti@sbu.edu | Peer Coach: Sara Neal, neals23@bonaventure.edu Office Hours: By appointment Monday-Thursday 9:00 am – 4:00 pm and Fridays 9:00 am – 3:30 pm Course description: This course will introduce the characteristics and functions of community and diversity, and explain how students belong and thrive at St. Bonaventure. The course will also teach students about effective learning strategies and aspects of college preparation and career development. By exploring facets of St. Bonaventure's mission, and what diversity, equity, and inclusion mean, students can engage in better-informed dialogue about their roles as citizens of the world. This course is for students in their first semester of college. General Education Learning Goals – view by clicking here. Course Learning Objectives Identify characteristics of a community and how they apply to St. Bonaventure. Analyze and critique a common experience such as film, book, or lecture. Explain effective learning strategies and skills, and demonstrate ways these strategies fit with their Bonaventure experience. Identify and evaluate concepts of well-being and life balance. Articulate degree requirements, policies, and procedures. Demonstrate technology and information literacy by articulating the ways that computers process and organize data, how information can be responsibly obtained and protected, and the overall impact of technology on society. Evaluate personal insights on strengths, informed decision making, and emotional intelligence -and their relevance to life decisions such as life goals and vocation selection and preparation. Increase awareness and understanding of diversity: students will know basic concepts of diversity and how these they intersect and impact individuals and society. Foster social justice: students will know how SBU promotes social justice and addresses issues related to diversity such as discrimination, prejudice, and inequality in our community. Academic Honesty: Academic dishonesty is inconsistent with the moral character expected of students in a University committed to the spiritual and intellectual growth of the whole person and with the ethics of the teaching profession. It also subverts the academic process by distorting all measurements. It is a serious matter and will be dealt with accordingly. A list of unacceptable practices, penalties to be assigned, and procedures to be followed in prosecuting cases of alleged academic dishonesty may be found in the Student Code of Conduct. Students should familiarize with these very important provisions. ADA Statement: Students with Disabilities: St. Bonaventure University strives to ensure the accessibility of its programs, classes, and services for all students. Students with disabilities who need academic accommodations should contact the Accessibility Services and Accommodations office, located on the first floor of Plassmann in room 108, at asa@sbu.edu or at 716-375-2115. Additional information about accommodations can be found here: https://www.sbu.edu/asa. Please reach out early in the semester so that we can assist you as soon as possible. Documentation from the Accessibility Services Office is required before the instructor can make accommodations. Grading: Total = 1000 points On-Campus Leader Reflections - 50 1 Scavenger Hunt – 50 1 Diversity Quiz – 100 points 1 Common Experience Presentation & Paper (Midterm) – 200 points (100 points each) 1 Community Paper (Final) – 200 points Attendance & Participation – 400 points Attendance Policy: 2 unexcused absences – please email me directly if you need to miss class. Participation: There will be on-campus speakers on various topics, all students are expected to attend and participate in discussion/activities. Extra Credit: Opportunities will be available throughout the semester Course Topics and Tentative Schedule
